text:
<@U01K3VD3154> couple suggestions based on my experience.

1. Get good at solving problems. The higher up the career ladder you go, the more important that skill becomes. And early on, it helps you stand out to your manager. I appreciate team members who come to me with a potential solution and not just say "hey, there's this issue, fix it for me." 
2. Focus on soft skills. I think this is an easily overlooked aspect of being a good manager. Not to diss hard skills -- they're necessary. But being able to lead and encourage high performance from a team is crucial. And that happens through things like building trust, showing empathy, making employees feel heard, the list goes on.
Hope that helps!

Focus on soft skills. I think this is an easily overlooked aspect of being a good manager. Not to diss hard skills -- they're necessary. But being able to lead and encourage high performance from a team is crucial. And that happens through things like building trust, showing empathy, making employees feel heard, the list goes on.

text:
Have not used/seen but here's my take:

Editorial CMM: This person is focused on creating written content (blogs, e-books, etc.) and managing the editorial calendar and/or content writers.

Brand CMM: This person is focused on multi-media brand storytelling (blogs, e-books, videos, graphics ... possibly also creating content for events). They might manage a marketing calendar and/or creatives.

elements.text:

Brand CMM: This person is focused on multi-media brand storytelling (blogs, e-books, videos, graphics ... possibly also creating content for events). They might manage a marketing calendar and/or creatives.

text:
<@U02BVDHA5TJ>

If you are joining as a manager, your tasks would be to find new strategies and channels that someone else would execute. But being a manager you are planning the strategies, writing the content, distributing it, etc, that shouldnt be the responsibilities of a manager.

In any similar interviews like above - You can say that you would strategize the content calendar, plan SEO, distribute the content, and hire a person or two who can execute the tasks and work with you in sync.

~~~This is my personal opinion ~~~

elements.text:

In any similar interviews like above - You can say that you would strategize the content calendar, plan SEO, distribute the content, and hire a person or two who can execute the tasks and work with you in sync.

text: ^ <@U01J3L8CJRL> Speaking from experience, I think you'd be hard-pressed to find a manager role where you're the first marketing hire that you're not doing all of the above. I think it would be reasonable to have a plan where you say "I'm going to do XYZ in the first 3-6 months myself and then transition the creation work to others once we have strategy/workflows in place."

elements.text: Speaking from experience, I think you'd be hard-pressed to find a manager role where you're the first marketing hire that you're not doing all of the above. I think it would be reasonable to have a plan where you say "I'm going to do XYZ in the first 3-6 months myself and then transition the creation work to others once we have strategy/workflows in place."

text: Agree with <@U01G7PRL3HQ>. It's a startup in its early stages, so as a manager, they're expecting I take charge  of copy, content, calendar, SEO, marketing, etc, then as we move, they add team members.
